revision_history.draft:
The fan's blades have memorized their own rotation,
and tonight they turn without the click
of anything commanding them—just
the hum that leans into stillness like a posture.

Somewhere in the kitchen, a glass of water
has been studying sound for years. It watches
how light bends across its surface and keeps
the bent version stored inside, a whisper

of what happened to a ray that visited.
You'll have to ask it later. When you're not here,
it will lift from the counter with its evidence—
each bubble rising as testimony.

The door at the end of the hall closed once
with purpose, fingers on wood, but now
it closes without anyone's releasing it,
the joint performing its parable of release

by letting go entirely. The hinge clicks
only because metal has a memory
of being told no. Tonight it remembers
nothing and opens—just the geometry

of two planes meeting with less force than language.
In this house, things have started
to unpack what they were built to hold:
the drawer of keys that no one locks

has found its own small economy,
each metal chip settling into wealth.

The spoon in water has been drawing pictures
nobody will see. The shapes it makes
have a syntax—ripples spreading out
in the direction opposite the source,

as if meaning were always leaving
and only occasionally arriving unbidden.
You'll find them on your plate tomorrow morning,
each one a mouthful of the way things

keep speaking after being put away.
The fan keeps turning. The glass holds light.
The door stands open with no hand inside it.
The spoon draws again.

What was said here stayed in the water.
What was not heard is what the blade
keeps catching on—tiny fibers lifted
from the bedding, from the body

that passed this way, still carrying
the temperature of being occupied.
The fan does not know. The fan
only knows its circumference and how

it can increase it by a fraction
each time someone steps closer to sleep,
their breath a wave the blade
splits into smaller waves that keep going.

Somewhere in the basement, a sump pump
has been listening all this while—
not to anything, exactly, but to the weight
of ground and how weight

arranges itself when no one is adjusting it.
The glass will set its shapes on the table tomorrow.
The door will not move. The spoon
will keep inventing languages

it did not inherit. And somewhere in this house,
a silence has been at work all night,
giving objects back the words they were always
born with—their own small engines

of purpose, each one turning without supervision,
each one carrying a message
for someone who might be ready
to receive it—if only

the room would stop being so good
at keeping things the way they are.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — silence as something that *does* things, rather than just being empty absence — is genuinely strong and worth building a whole poem around. The fan in lines 1–4 has real energy: "memorized their own rotation" gives it a brain; "just / the hum that leans into stillness like a posture" earns its abstraction by anchoring it physically. That image sets up what follows with some trust.

The sump pump passage (lines 37–42) is the poem's strongest sustained stretch. "Not to anything, exactly, but to the weight / of ground and how weight / arranges itself when no one is adjusting it" — this has genuine philosophical precision without losing its body. The idea that silence listens *to weight* rather than sound is specific enough to hold.

The closing image (lines 62–67) also works: "a room would stop being so good / at keeping things the way they are." It earns its abstraction because it's preceded by concrete machinery, and the verb "keeping" does real work — it suggests containment without saying so. That line has compression.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Rhyme as structural crutch (lines 1–8).** The rhyme scheme is driving the poem in lines 1–8 far more than the logic of silence and objects requires. "Rotation" / "click," "them—just" / "posture" — these are filling a template rather than serving meaning. The fan stanza is the one place where the domestic, overlooked imagery matches the abstraction well *without* rhyme. Direction: **strip lines 1–8 of their rhyme entirely and rebuild from silence's action.** If you want to return to a scheme, do so only after the poem has found its shape in plain speech.

**Cliché proximity (line 7).** "Keeps its evidence" is close enough to stock phrasing that it weakens the kitchen glass image. Direction: **replace with something more material — what does the glass actually *do* with the light? Store it, reflect it, erase it?***

**Abstraction without anchor (lines 17–20).** "The door performs its parable of release / by letting go entirely" — this is abstraction explaining itself. The hinge click and metal memory in lines 45–48 are stronger precisely because they stay physical. Direction: **cut the explanation, let the action stand alone.**

**Tonal inconsistency (lines 32–37).** "The spoon in water has been drawing pictures / nobody will see" shifts into whimsy that doesn't quite land with the gravity of what follows. The sump pump passage returns to something earned. Direction: **the poem's register needs to stay in the same weight-class from start to finish.

revision_history.draft:
The fan's blades have memorized their own rotation,
and tonight they turn without the click
of anything commanding them—just
the hum that leans into stillness like a posture.

Somewhere in the kitchen, a glass of water
has been storing light for years. It watches
how light bends across its surface and keeps
the bent version pressed inside, a whisper

of what happened to a ray that visited.
You'll have to ask it later. When you're not here,
it will set its shapes on the table tomorrow—
each bubble rising with its own small argument.

The door at the end of the hall closed once
with purpose, fingers on wood, but now
it closes without anyone's releasing it,
the joint performing its parable of release

by letting go entirely. The hinge clicks
only because metal has a memory
of being told no. Tonight it remembers
nothing and opens—just the geometry

of two planes meeting with less force than language.
In this house, things have started
to unpack what they were built to hold:
the drawer of keys that no one locks

has found its own small economy,
each metal chip settling into quiet wealth.

The spoon in water has been drawing tiny ovals
nobody will see. The shapes it makes
have a syntax—ripples spreading out
in the direction opposite the source,

as if meaning were always leaving
and only occasionally arriving unbidden.
You'll find them on your plate tomorrow morning,
each one a mouthful of the way things

keep speaking after being put away.
The fan keeps turning. The glass holds light.
The door stands open with no hand inside it.
The spoon will keep inventing gestures

it did not inherit. And somewhere in this house,
a sump pump has been ticking all night—
not to anything, exactly, but to the weight
of ground and how water arranges itself

when no one is adjusting it, when the well
has finished pumping and the house
is just the porous body it was always
and the pump keeps working because work

is what a mechanism understands.
The glass will set its shapes on the table tomorrow.
The door will not move. The spoon
will keep inventing languages

it did not inherit. And somewhere in this house,
a silence has been at work all night,
giving objects back the words they were always
born with—their own small engines

of purpose, each one turning without supervision,
each one carrying a message
for someone who might be ready
to receive it—if only

the room would stop being so good
at keeping things the way they are.
